awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for the Electrification of the Chemical Industry (CECI)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The chemical industry is one of the largest consumers of energy and changing its energy source from coal and natural gas to renewable electricity would have significant impact on reducing carbon dioxide emissions and on reversing climate change.  In traditional chemical plants energy needed but not produced in the plant is supplied by burning fossil fuels and transported around the plant as high pressure and temperature steam. The global chemical manufacturing infrastructure has been based on this model since the beginning of the industrial revolution. In contrast, the future electrified chemical plant will rely on fundamentally different unit operations powered by electrochemistry. This project envisions for transforming the present-day chemical industry from an enterprise that relies on fossil-fuel-derived heat as power source to one that is based on renewable electricity. Towards this end, plans for initiating the formation of an Engineering Research Center for Electrification of the Chemical Industry (CECI) are proposed.  This team proposes to engage a broad and diverse group of experts and stakeholders through a call for solutions to CECI's target technology needs and a workshop to generate actionable ideas and interdependent research tasks. The goals are (1) to facilitate the formation of a community vested in CECI's vision, (2) to identify and bring together the necessary skills and capabilities to surpass the existing barriers for the electrification of the chemical industry, (3) to plant the seeds for the formation of a community and the accompanying.

CECI will concentrate on three key bottlenecks for the deployment of electrochemical manufacturing on large scale: electrochemical reactors, electrochemical separation units, and electrochemical energy recycling. The technological development in these three technology areas will be supported by exploration on four research platforms: components, unit operations, systems integration, and societal impact. The component research platform will comprise a team of chemists, material scientists and chemical engineers who will develop membranes, electrocatalysts, and molecular redox energy carriers that satisfy the needs of the unit operations. The unit operations platform will comprise chemical, electrical, and mechanical engineers who will develop electrochemical cells that incorporate the components developed in CECI to impact each of the three technology areas. The systems integration platform will comprise power and systems engineers who will develop protocols to integrate unit operations with each other, renewable energy generators, and/or the electric grid. The impact research platform will comprise, energy economists and sustainability experts who will develop and employ techno-economical and life-cycle assessment tools to provide CECI with societal, economic, and environmental welfare targets. This multi-level interdisciplinary and ambitious effort would only be possible through large convergent research approaches enabled by an NSF ERC.  CECI will aim to reduce the overall energy consumption and cost, making its impact on the society both environmental and economical. Importantly, CECI will educate the next generation of scientists and engineers with technical, entrepreneurial, and communication skills necessary for realizing CECI's vision. The diverse CECI team will also endow these students with policy knowledge and awareness necessary for successful implementation of technological advances achieved by CECI. The New York Metropolitan area and surrounding states (e.g., New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut), is well-suited for nucleating and assembling the CECI team because it provides access to a diverse population of students, an abundance of higher education institutions, including some designated as minority-serving, proximity to chemical companies and capital, and a well-established culture of innovation and entrepreneurship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The chemical industry is a vital contributor to human progress because it is at the foundation of supply chains that provide us with nearly all the products we use in our day-to-day lives: life-saving drugs, personal care products, transportation fuels, agricultural fertilizers, and pesticides, among others. The chemical industry continues to propel humans to new highs in living standards but primarily by using energy from fossil fuels. Chemical plants use thermochemical reactors, which must be heated while synthesizing products, and these products must be purified subsequently by energy-intensive processes such as distillation. In this scheme (Figure 1 left), energy is supplied typically by burning coal or natural gas. Unfortunately, with this established paradigm, the chemical industry also contributes to one of humanity's biggest challenges, CO2 emissions, accelerating and exacerbating anthropogenic climate change.

Intellectual Merit - This center planning project aimed to assemble an interdisciplinary team of academic researchers to conduct the research needed to transform the present-day chemical industry, from an enterprise that relies on fossil-fuel-derived heat as a power source (Figure 1, left) to one that is based on renewable electricity (Figure 1 right). The goal was to generate actionable ideas and interdependent research tasks from a diverse group of stakeholders, engage them in the vision, and facilitate the formation of a community of researchers, engineers, and executives vested in this vision illustrated in Figure 1.

Broader Impacts - Electrification of the chemical industry and rising renewables in the grid supply can potentially eliminate 30% of the US Industries CO2 emissions. Thus, the overarching goal has a high societal impact and requires a center approach because of the complexity of goals and diversity of disciplines needed to achieve the vision.

A virtual day-long workshop was organized and held online on June 3, 2020. The workshop was attended by approximately 30 faculty and researchers from academic institutions and government labs and over 50 scientists, engineers, and executives representing 25 companies. The companies included chemical manufacturing conglomerates and pharmaceutical companies, their equipment, feedstock, and service suppliers, utility providers, renewable energy companies, and startups. The workshop agenda included talks by faculty and industry on recent progress and research towards electrifying chemical processes using (1) electrochemical reactors, (2) plasma reactors, and (3) membrane separations. These processes derive energy from electricity such that increased use of renewables would eliminate CO2 emissions. The workshop also included talks on integrating these processes into existing chemical plants and/or new designs and integrating electrified chemical plants with the power grid. Vigorous discussions were held in breakout sessions to identify barriers to the transformation of the chemical manufacturing industry from one that relies on fossil-fuel-derived heat as a power source to one that is based on renewable electricity. These barriers included (1) lack of scalable and cost-competitive electrochemical reactors for major chemical transformations, (2) lack of design rules for selective, energy-efficient, and high-throughput electrocatalysts and membranes; (3) lack of plasma-catalysis and plasma-membrane reactor concepts and scale-up guidelines; (4) lack of adequate fundamental understanding to control catalysts? interfaces with electrolytes and/or plasma; (5) the lack of understanding of mechanisms, transport, and kinetics at plasma-catalyst and -membrane interfaces; (6) lack of an underlying understanding of the relationship between the electrocatalysts and electrolytes composition and structure; (7) lack of available efficient, high-throughput, cost-effective and stable membrane separation units for light olefin-paraffin mixtures in the gas phase or for benzene-toluene-xylene in the liquid phase; (8) lack of scalable structure-property-performance relationships for the membrane composites; and (9) cost-effective integration of electrocatalysts and membranes into chemical reaction and separation units. Goals were discussed and identified by experts in academia, national labs, and industry who can help achieve these goals. The directions, opportunities, and research areas relevant to the overarching goal of electrifying chemical manufacturing included novel electrochemical reactor design, development of selective and efficient electrocatalysts, durable membranes for separations, process intensification, plasma catalysis and plasma reactors for chemical synthesis, and research addressing potential issues in integrating electrified chemical plants into the electricity grid. The co-principal investigators also interviewed and engaged faculty and experts on environmental law and industrial organization transformations, who can design economic policy framework and organization transformation process to enable an economically viable transition towards a decarbonized chemical industry, together with community engagement and adoption strategies required for this transformation.

A strategic plan to catalyze the decarbonization of the chemical industry by innovating chemical manufacturing processes powered by renewable electricity grids was developed. This strategic plan led to and provided the basis for the formation of the Center for Decarbonizing Chemical Manufacturing Using Sustainable Electrification (DC-MUSE) center. A webpage (www.dc-muse.org) and an informational video were created (https://youtu.be/vHUe_tQo1MU) to communicate the mission of DC-MUSE and serve as a virtual space for the center. A well-integrated multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional team of experts was assembled and is actively involved in the growth of the DC-MUSE center.
